item.title: Trump isn't the first to push an unproven claim about autism. Why are they so pervasive?
item.description: One expert says an "information void" has allowed non-evidence-based claims and conspiracy theories around autism to flourish.

item.title: Afraid of AI replacing you? Here are jobs that may be future-proof
item.description: Jobs including tax preparation, legal advice and education may have the lowest risk of being replaced by technology.

item.title: 'Is this still happening?': Elon Musk named in new Epstein files
item.description: Prince Andrew and PayPal co-founder Peter Thiel are among the other names in the documents released by Democrat politicians.

item.title: 'Peeling back the water': How these women are mapping ancient whale migration paths
item.description: A trio of First Nations researchers is blending traditional knowledge and science to map whale migration and advocate for improved conservation.

item.title: 'Jekyll and Hyde': How to win over Australia's most polarising bird
item.description: Culturally revered in Dreamtime stories but feared by cyclists, the magpie has a "Jekyll and Hyde" presence in our suburbs. But one expert says there are ways to win them over — even if you're magpie enemy number one.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Footballer Fandi Ahmad is a Singaporean sporting legend: We find out why
item.description: Fandi Ahmad is more than just a footballer; has been described as a national legend in Singapore. He was the first Singaporean footballer to play in Europe, the first Singaporean millionaire sportsperson and the first Singaporean sportsperson to have a published biography. As a young child, his family lived in a two-room public housing flat, Fandi was obsessed with football and spent much of his time kicking a ball. He became arguably Asia's best known footballer. He's shared the pitch with Diego Maradona, and was picked to play for Dutch football giant Ajax - an offer he subsequently turned down. Fandi's Muslim faith is central to his life. He avoids scandals, does not smoke or drink, and has been described as humble, filial, and compassionate. In this extended edition of Weekend One on One, he talks to SBS's Christopher Tan

item.title: INTERVIEW: 'We are family, we should work together': Palau President's challenge to Australia
item.description: Palau, an independent island nation in the western Pacific Ocean, consists of more than 300 islands in Micronesia. It's a popular destination for divers and ecotourists and visitors are required to take the "Palau Pledge" to protect its ecosystems. But Palau is already facing the immediate reality of climate change, with rising sea levels, coral bleaching, extreme weather events, and biodiversity loss. Surangel Whipps Junior, the President of Palau, has spoken at the United Nations General Assembly in New York, and wants to see the COP31 global climate conference held in the Pacific region rather than in Turkiye, because this is where climate change is already having devastating impacts. He's been talking to SBS Senior International Correspondent Ben Lewis, and told him that Palau and Australia are family - and the two countries need to work together.

item.title: The effects of Tonga's massive volcanic explosion linger, three years on
item.description: It's been more than three and a half years since one of the most powerful volcanic eruptions in recent history left devastation in Tonga. An Australian-led scientific team has been studying the area surrounding the underwater volcano, in collaboration with researchers from across the world, looking for signs of life. The eruption changed the shape of the sea floor and devastated the underwater environment but early signs of life are beginning to emerge.

item.title: Russia says West will 'very much regret' any aggressive action inside its airspace
item.description: The Russian foreign minister also said that only the "politically blind" would expect Ukraine to return to pre-2022 borders, an indirect response to a recent assertion made by the US president.

item.title: Donald Trump deploys troops into another US city, authorising use of 'full force, if necessary'
item.description: The Portland mayor and Oregon governor have both rejected Donald Trump's planned deployment of the US military into the north-western city.

item.title: The hidden form of sexual assault you may not know about
item.description: Stealthing — the removal of a condom during sex without a partner's knowledge or consent — is criminalised in most of Australia. But experts warn many people remain unaware of what it is and the risks it poses.

item.title: The hidden form of sexual assault you may not know about
item.description: Stealthing — the removal of a condom during sex without a partner's knowledge or consent — is criminalised in most of Australia. But experts warn many people remain unaware of what it is and the risks it poses.

item.title: What to know about UN's 'snapback' sanctions on Iran, reimposed after a decade
item.description: The "snapback" process reactivates UN resolutions, but their practical implementation requires UN member states to update their laws to comply.

item.title: Russia's major drone and missile attack on Ukraine kills four in Kyiv
item.description: Russia rained down 643 drones and missiles, including glide bombs, across eastern, central and southern Ukraine, Ukraine's general staff said.

item.title: Nuclear bombs on drones: The next arms race that has experts 'very concerned'
item.description: While drones flying over different parts of Europe have raised concerns in many countries, some are worried about a more dystopian future with the technology.

item.title: In America's war on autism, families like Eileen's are on the frontline
item.description: US health secretary Robert F Kennedy Jr has faced widespread criticism over his comments about autism. And in a changing America, community members from all parts of the spectrum are navigating societal and political divisions.

item.title: Jobs and wages boost budget bottom line ahead of Tuesday's interest rates call
item.description: Strong jobs and wages numbers have more than halved the budget deficit that was projected last financial year.

item.title: SBS News In Easy English 29 September 2025
item.description: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners, and people with a disability.

item.title: 'Weird weather': Why this year's spring and summer just became tricky to predict
item.description: A clash of wind and air currents 30km above Antarctica has suddenly thrown Australia's spring and summer weather forecast into question.

item.title: Tony Blair: Ruler of Gaza? Why the former British leader is suddenly in the frame
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has praised former UK prime minister Tony Blair for his "constructive" involvement in the Middle East.

item.title: What happened to an Australian republic? Why Albanese has quashed the idea
item.description: The prime minister isn't willing to risk his renewed political capital by holding another referendum, experts argue.

item.title: Brisbane Broncos light up sharemarket & final budget outcome revealed
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Stephen Smith from Deloitte Access Economics abut what the government's final budget outcome says about the economy; plus Kyle Rodda from Capital.com on the day's sharemarket action.

item.title: 'Significant discrepancies' found in imported melatonin products, medical regulator warns
item.description: Testing of unregulated melatonin revealed one product contained four times its labelled amount, while another did not have any at all.

item.title: Here are the travel destinations Australians are heading to this spring
item.description: Many Australians will be heading out of state or the country this spring but cost is proving to be one of the greatest barriers for making plans.

item.title: First Nations youth train as firefighters to defend Country and Community: 'I want to make a difference'
item.description: A group of young First Nations men and women have blazed their way through a training program for firefighter hopefuls. The initiative is a partnership between TAFE and the New South Wales Fire Service - to help young Indigenous people get into their dream job.

item.title: Natural disasters are growing; could an army of young volunteers help?
item.description: Could a 'Climate Army' of young volunteers bolster Australia's capability to cope with natural disasters? That's the question before a Senate inquiry looking at proposals for a new national scheme.

item.title: Dozens killed as Typhoon Bualoi batters Vietnam and Philippines
item.description: In Vietnam, Bualoi made landfall as a typhoon late on Sunday, generating winds of 130 kmh.

item.title: 'They destroy lives': How property investors lost millions to a failed housing scheme
item.description: A group of Iranians were told that investing in Australian specialist disability accommodation would be as safe as houses. However, those plans never eventuated, and they've collectively lost $1,178,500.

item.title: Spouses for sale: Inside the black market for skilled visa applications
item.description: SBS has uncovered a black market operating on apps targeting members of the Chinese community, selling places for "spouses" in permanent residency skilled visa applications.

item.title: Australia supports Trump's 20-point Gaza peace plan backed by Israel
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said the country "welcomes President Trump's plan to bring peace to Gaza after almost two years of conflict and a devastating loss of civilian life".

item.title: Australia supports Trump's 20-point Gaza peace plan backed by Israel
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said the country "welcomes President Trump's plan to bring peace to Gaza after almost two years of conflict and a devastating loss of civilian life".

item.title: Vital role of translators celebrated amid AI challenge
item.description: It's been eight years since the United Nations first recognised International Translation Day. The celebration falls on 30 September and recognises the work of language professionals who foster cultural understanding, connection and social cohesion. But some translators and interpreters in Australia believe more needs to be done to protect the workforce and bridge language barriers.

item.title: Albanese invites Arab 'hypermarket' to compete with Coles and Woolworths
item.description: As Australia grapples with a supermarket monopoly, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese hopes the expansion of this Emirati "hypermarket" might bring in some competition.

item.title: JK Rowling lashes out at 'ignorant' Emma Watson over trans rights row
item.description: The author criticised the Harry Potter star, who said in a recent interview that she can still love people with whom she disagrees.

item.title: SBS News In Easy English 30 September 2025
item.description: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Not the outcome Australians wanted, Chalmers says, as Reserve Bank holds cash rate
item.description: The Reserve Bank of Australia board was widely tipped to hold the cash rate after inflation data showed successive rises.

item.title: 'Disappointing': Critics say Riyadh Comedy Festival has an unfunny human rights problem
item.description: Comedy heavyweights including Dave Chappelle, Jimmy Carr and Louis CK are on the bill of the Riyadh Comedy Festival.

item.title: New guidelines developed for helping people with dementia
item.description: A framework has been developed to track and improve the treatment options for dementia patients in aged care. The proposal come after the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare named dementia as the leading cause of death in Australia.

item.title: Key questions around the 'tone deaf, very tricky' Trump-Netanyahu Gaza peace plan
item.description: A United States proposal for peace in Gaza has received endorsement from Israel and the Palestinian Authority, but its long-term success is on a knife-edge.

item.title: The PM's new supermarket proposal might cut your bills, but it's 'no silver bullet'
item.description: The prime minister needs to consider preconditions, such as space and a break-up of Coles and Woolworths, if he wants a competing supermarket to thrive and bring down prices.

item.title: 'The pinnacle': One of Australia's most dominant teams aims at 40-year record
item.description: Australia's women's cricket side take on New Zealand in their first World Cup match.

item.title: RBA holds fire; energy stock sell-off
item.description: Despite solid gains by the gold miners, a sell-off in energy stocks – fuelled by a continued decline in oil prices – has dragged the Australian sharemarket. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Jonathan Shead, Head of Investment at State Street Investment Management. Plus, the Reserve Bank left interest rates unchanged at 3.6 percent, as expected, at its September board meeting. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Pradeep Philip from Deloitte Access Economics.

item.title: Decision to allow registered nurses to prescribe medicines solves many health service problems
item.description: Tens of thousands of registered nurses across the country will be able to up-skill to prescribe medications usually authorised by a doctor. It's a reform that could change the medical landscape in Australia... and the lives of many patients.

item.title: Pizza, porn, and getting high: Inside the grip of a severe tech addiction
item.description: Technology seems a non-negotiable part of everyday life. For Quentin, it became an addiction. After years of trying different ways to break free, it was a 12-step program that helped her into recovery.

item.title: Fast entry or backwards step? What Labor's new housing scheme means for you
item.description: Analysis shows the government's new First Home Guarantee scheme could slash years off savings times — but experts warn it could come at a cost.

item.title: Nicole Kidman files for divorce from Keith Urban, citing 'irreconcilable differences'
item.description: Oscar-winning star Nicole Kidman and Grammy-winning country musician Keith Urban had been living apart for some time, according to US media reports.

item.title: A new push for peace: What part did Australia play in the 20-point plan for Gaza?
item.description: Anthony Albanese's stopover in the Middle East came after more lengthy engagements in the US — for the leaders' week at the United Nations — and the UK.

item.title: The US government has shut down. What happens now?
item.description: The US government has entered a shutdown, meaning thousands of federal employees are being placed on leave or asked to work without pay until the government reopens.

item.title: Albanese 'concerned' over China's reported BHP iron ore ban
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese hopes a pricing dispute between China and the Australian mining giant will be resolved "very quickly".

item.title: SBS News In Easy English 1 October 2025
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Magnitude-6.9 earthquake kills more than 70 people in the Philippines
item.description: The quake, which struck off the central island of Cebu, was the country's deadliest in more than a decade.

item.title: It happened 'by accident', but Mark is helping tackle a $2.7bn Australian problem
item.description: Loneliness among men has been described as a "crisis" in Australia, and its estimated to cost the health system billions each year.

item.title: BHP-China iron ore stand-off; house prices continue to rise
item.description: The Australian sharemarket has fallen flat, as investors react to the US government shutdown and reports of China temporarily banning purchases of BHP’s iron ore. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Niv Dagan from Peak Asset Management. Plus, Australian house prices continue to rise, as the Albanese Government’s Home Guarantee scheme is expanded to all first home buyers. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Tim Lawless, Asia-Pacific research director at Cotality.

item.title: A new First Nations voice to guide Australia's public health sector
item.description: The Public Health Association of Australia has announced they will be establishing an Aboriginal and Torres-Strait Islander voice to help guide their work after a near unanimous vote by their members. Nearly two years after the failed referendum saw a First Nations voice to parliament shot down, NGOs like the PHAA and state governments have chosen to follow the wishes of the majority of Indigenous communities in Australia who voted for this special representation.

item.title: INTERVIEW: What does the US shutdown mean in practice?
item.description: The U.S. federal government has entered a shutdown, a few hours after the U.S. Senate failed to pass a short-term spending bill on Tuesday night US East Coast time. It's the first government shutdown in nearly seven years. The last and also the longest federal government shutdown occurred from late 2018 to early 2019 during President Trump's first term when Democrats opposed funding the U.S.-Mexico border wall. The result was a shutdown lasting over five weeks, during which some 800,000 federal employees were forced to work without pay or take unpaid leave. Hundreds of thousands of federal employees will be forced to take unpaid leave this time too, with some public services potentially suspended or delayed, and the release of economic data possibly impacted as well. Bruce Wolpe is a senior fellow at the University of Sydney's United States Studies Centre and has served on the Democratic staff in the US Congress. He's been speaking to SBS's Virginia Langeberg about the impact of the shutdown.

item.title: 'No more signs of life': Dozens remain missing after Indonesian school collapse
item.description: After days of rescue operations, 59 people were still feared buried under the rubble after at least five people had been confirmed dead.

item.title: Is your sunscreen safe? What to know amid Australia's SPF ratings storm
item.description: Eighteen sunscreens have either been recalled or had their sale paused in Australia. Here's what you need to know as the weather gets warmer.

item.title: In a battle to build, these five charts show Labor's housing headache
item.description: There are doubts major inroads into Australia's housing supply problem can be made in a couple of years and questions over the government's "ambitious" 2029 target. So, what can be done?

item.title: I started feeling sick making lunch — and never could've expected what came next
item.description: Corinne Laurent doesn’t believe she would still be alive if not for her smartwatch.

item.title: Wildlife advocate and primate expert Jane Goodall dies at 91
item.description: The renowned conservationist, scientist, and global activist Jane Goodall has died at the age of 91. The Jane Goodall Institute announced the primatologist's death of natural causes on social media.

item.title: See the full list: The biggest Australian companies paying the least tax
item.description: Australia's largest companies paid $95.7 billion in taxes, with those paying zero dropping to an 11-year low.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 2nd October 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Albanese welcomes PNG's decision to sign landmark defence pact
item.description: The pact will elevate the Pacific partnership, ensuring an attack on one would be a "danger to the peace and security of both countries".

item.title: Albanese welcomes PNG's decision to sign landmark defence pact
item.description: The pact will elevate the Pacific partnership, ensuring an attack on one would be a "danger to the peace and security of both countries".

item.title: Government shutdown begins as division rules Washington
item.description: Washington has ground to a halt thanks to a government shutdown, triggered by Congress being unable to agree on a funding bill. It is the 15th government shutdown since 1981, which will likely slow the release of key reports and lead to the furlough of 750,000 federal workers at a daily cost of $US400 million.

item.title: Animal shelter accused of having 'blood on its hands' after euthanising 12-week-old puppy
item.description: A couple who had fostered the dog, Murphy, had called Victoria's Lost Dogs Home to ask how he was going, only to be told he would be put down.

item.title: Australian men face loneliness crisis: what’s driving it and how to fix it
item.description: Loneliness among men has been described as a "crisis" in Australia, and it appears to be on the rise. This social isolation can not only hurt mens mental health and overall wellbeing, it is also costing the Australian economy billions of dollars. A recent Australian study could hold the answer as to why men appear to be stuggling more with loneliness.

item.title: Gaza peace plan, US shuts down & China combats whingers
item.description: A new 20-point plan for peace in Gaza gains support among the international community. Trump warns the US military of the enemy from within as Hegseth tells Generals to slim down for the war on woke. Plus, Democrats and Republicans point the finger at each other as the US government shuts down. Also, Moscow warns of a new red line in the war in Ukraine. And, China launches a campaign to stamp out online negativity.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Israeli forces take action against flotilla trying to deliver aid
item.description: Israeli military personnel have intercepted an international flotilla trying to deliver medicine and food to Gaza and boarded its boats as it approached the area. The Global Sumud Flotilla consists of more than 40 civilian boats carrying about 500 parliamentarians, lawyers and activists including Swedish climate campaigner Greta Thunberg. The organisers say they are trying to break Israel's blockade of Gaza, despite repeated warnings from Israel to turn back. The United Nations last month ruled that Israel had committed genocide in Gaza, a claim Israel denies. Israel has imposed a naval blockade on Gaza since Hamas took control of the coastal enclave in 2007 and they claim it is a legal part of the action they are taking against Hamas. They've accused the flotilla of having connections to Hamas - which the organisers strongly deny, while other critics accuse them of grandstanding. Judy Patterson's son, Hamish, is the captain of the Wahoo, one of the ships taking part in the action, and she spoke to SBS's Tee Mitchell.

item.title: Nuclear energy sank the Coalition at the election — can it power their comeback?
item.description: The coalition are revamping their proposal for nuclear energy, despite suffering an election loss with this policy. The details are yet to be confirmed, but the Opposition Energy Minister says they will adapt their plan to meet developments in the space.

item.title: NIMBYs, YIMBYs — and BIMBYs: The new group in Australia's housing stoush
item.description: As state governments roll out plans to battle Australia's housing crisis, community groups are mobilising to have a say in how their suburbs are — or are not — changed.

item.title: ASX rallies despite US government shutdown
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Callam Pickering about the latest household spending data and what it means for interest rates, plus Henry Jennings from Marcus Today on the days market action.

item.title: Police say they 'will not rest' despite scaling back search for boy missing in outback
item.description: No significant evidence was found to indicate where Gus may have gone during the massive search involving police, defence force personnel and large numbers of volunteers.

item.title: Why experts are 'rewriting' Australia's bushfire risk this summer
item.description: Unusual weather patterns and climate change are raising concerns for parts of Australia, as well as popular travel destinations.

item.title: New trick Australians are using to 'maximise' tax returns — but beware of the risks
item.description: It might be free to use and readily available, but it could also be giving incorrect advice.

item.title: UK government promises greater security for Jewish community after deadly synagogue attack in Manchester
item.description: A WARNING THAT THE FOLLOWING STORY CONTAINS CONTENT THAT MAY BE DISTRESSING FOR SOME LISTENERS Two people have been killed and three others seriously hurt after an assailant drove a car into pedestrians and stabbed a security guard near a synagogue in Manchester in northern England. Greater Manchester Police say officers shot and killed the suspect, who investigators say attacked just as Jewish communities around the world mark Yom Kippur, the holiest holiday in the Jewish calendar.

item.title: What is the Global Sumud Flotilla - and why has Israel intercepted it?
item.description: Israeli naval forces have intercepted the Global Sumud Flotilla, seizing more than 40 civilian boats and hundreds of activists - including Australians. The action has sparked global protests and condemnation, with Israel saying it is necessary for its own security.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 3 October 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Footy, culture, and so much more: welcome to the Koori knockout
item.description: This weekend will see the largest annual gathering of Indigenous people in the country at the New South Wales Koori knockout rugby league tournament. It's a sporting competition... but also, so much more.

item.title: Forwards or backwards? Daylight saving starts soon — here's what to know
item.description: Here's everything you need to know, including tips on how to adjust.

item.title: When do the 2025 NRL and NRLW grand finals start? Here's everything you need to know
item.description: It will be a busy day of footy on Sunday with both the NRL and NRLW grand finals taking place. Here's what you need to know.

item.title: Oil prices tumble to 4 month low as ASX edges closer to record high
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Dianne Colledge from Morgans Financial Limited about the days sharemarket action including the opportunites for investors.

item.title: 'No evidence' blueberries unsafe to eat, watchdogs say, after banned pesticide concerns
item.description: The berry industry welcomed the finding, with a key figure saying it was "devastating" to have been "wrongfully targeted". The researcher who raised the concerns says that wasn't her intention.

item.title: 'The 99 per cent are not your enemy': Genesis Owusu on power, politics and racism
item.description: Genesis Owusu has battled racism, depression and industry pressures — but his third album is his most direct yet. He says it’s a blunt call for truth in an era of division.

item.title: 700 Australians were recruited for a yoga study. What researchers found surprised them
item.description: Many older Australians who practice yoga say it gives them strength and confidence, but a new study suggests one particular type of yoga could be associated with a higher risk of falls.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Could a First Nations voice help tackle stubborn public health challenges?
item.description: Nearly two years after the failed referendum saw a First Nations voice to parliament shot down, some NGOs and state governments have been taking the initiative to follow the wishes of the majority of Indigenous communities in Australia who voted for this special representation. Australia's principal non-government organisation for public health, the Public Health Association of Australia, has announced they will be instituting an Aboriginal and Torres-Strait Islander voice to help guide their work after a near unanimous vote by their members. SBS spoke to Dr Summer May Finlay, a Yorta Yorta woman, an Associate Professor at the University of Wollongong and the Vice President (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander) of the Public Health Association about the importance of a First Nations voice in helping to Close the Gap on healthcare outcomes between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians

item.title: INTERVIEW: Everyone loves a ghost train: but why do we love being scared?
item.description: Scary movies, haunted houses and trick or treating, October is the unofficial start to “spooky season” - at least, that's what you would think judging by what's on the shelves in our local shops. Sarah Kollat, teaching professor of psychology at Penn State University in the US, says there are lots of reasons people like to be scared. At a chemical level, our brains and bodies are reacting to the jump scares in a movie and “surviving” a haunted house. But psychologists also say getting scared in a safe environment prepares us for real danger.

item.title: Sean 'Diddy' Combs sentenced to more than four years in prison
item.description: In an address to the court before the US district judge imposed the sentence, Combs apologised to his victims, saying his behaviour was "disgusting, shameful and sick."

item.title: 'I support Sussan': Andrew Hastie denies resignation about leadership push
item.description: The Liberal MP's exit from the Opposition front bench comes after he publicly pushed for net-zero emissions goals to be dropped and migration to be curbed.

item.title: Australian officials 'on the ground' helping Gaza flotilla activists detained in Israel
item.description: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade says at least five Australians are detained in Israel, while Global Sumud Flotilla organisers say Israel has seven Australians in custody.

item.title: The major sticking points that could still upend the partially accepted Gaza peace deal
item.description: One expert says a hostage-prisoner exchange between Israel and Hamas is "highly likely" to go ahead, but he and others remain wary about the prospects for other parts of a Gaza peace deal.

item.title: 'I passed out multiple times at work': The health problem costing Australia billions
item.description: Endometriosis affects one in seven Australian women, yet experts warn workplaces remain years behind in providing support for those living with this "invisible" condition.

item.title: Why Joel spends his evenings being stabbed in the head with skewers — for fun
item.description: Blood, thumbtacks, fire, cactus plants and even whipper snippers. Welcome to the world of Australian deathmatch wrestling.

item.title: Yazidi refugees in Toowoomba find community through hockey
item.description: The Queensland city of Toowoomba has become home to thousands of Yazidi refugees. A local hockey program is aiming to develop confidence and language skills for this community, with the help of retired locals on the field.

item.title: Smooth Snake slithering its way back to life in the UK
item.description: Snakes may be ten a penny here in Australia but in the UK it's a different story. Britain's rarest reptile, known as the Smooth Snake, is thriving again after conservation efforts were introduced to save it in 2009. But monitoring exactly how many Smooth Snakes there are can be a challenge due to the reptile's reclusive nature.

item.title: Location-tracking apps: A harmful invasion of privacy or a great tool to keep loved ones safe?
item.description: With consent, location-tracking can be immensely useful in some situations, experts say, but they warn that the technology is certainly not without potential harms and can lead to controlling and coercive behaviours.

item.title: 'Determination and ingenuity': Australia's oldest man just turned 112
item.description: Ken Weeks was still walking into town for shopping after he turned 100 more than a decade ago.

item.title: We now know when your HECS debt will be slashed, and by how much
item.description: About three million Australians with a student debt will soon see their balance owed reduced.

item.title: A Thatcher-loving heavy metal drummer: Meet Japan's first female PM-in-waiting
item.description: Sanae Takaichi has repeatedly referred to former UK leader Margaret Thatcher as a source of inspiration.

item.title: Trump authorises deployment of 300 national guard troops to Chicago
item.description: The state's governor said it was "absolutely outrageous and un-American to demand a governor send military troops within our own borders and against our will".

item.title: 'Heartbreaking': The children Australia won’t bring home from a Syrian detention camp
item.description: The women and children who recently smuggled themselves out of a Syrian detention camp and returned to Australia proved that the government could bring its citizens home if it had the will, advocates say.

item.title: Israelis like Michal and Yarden act as 'human shields' in the West Bank. They've been called traitors
item.description: As the second anniversary of October 7 and Israel’s war in Gaza approaches, settler violence in the West Bank is steadily escalating. A small number of Israelis like Yarden want to end the 'status quo' — and they're willing to act as human shields to achieve it.

item.title: Government summons Optus, Telstra to Canberra over triple-zero failings
item.description: From 1 November, telcos will be required to provide real-time updates on network failures.

item.title: 'We do not see any change': Israel pounds Gaza despite Trump's call for end to bombing
item.description: There was no let-up in Israeli attacks on Gaza over the weekend as planes and tanks pounded areas across the enclave.

item.title: Zelenskyy criticises world 'silence' after yet another large-scale Russian attack
item.description: Five people have died after the Russian military attacked Ukraine overnight with 53 missiles and several waves of drones.

item.title: Space monster: gas-guzzling rogue planet eats all in its path
item.description: It sounds like the plot of a science fiction movie from the 1950s - a giant rogue planet, moving through the galaxy at a record-breaking speed, consuming vast quantities of dust and gas . But this isn't the product of the fevered imagination of a Hollywood writer. This lone planet is very real.

item.title: It's on Australia's 'do not travel' list. But influencers are promoting it anyway
item.description: A surge of travel vloggers is putting Afghanistan back on the tourism map, even as the Taliban tightens restrictions on women and security risks remain high.

item.title: The Australians who think it's fine to steal, and those who disagree
item.description: A new survey found a generational divide when it comes to rationalising retail theft behaviours, including scanning items incorrectly at self-checkout.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 6 October 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: 'Equals, mates, and now allies': What is the new treaty between Australia and PNG?
item.description: Australia has signed its first alliance in 70 years. In a battle for Pacific influence, is it a threat to China?

item.title: 'Undignified': Albanese criticises Greens leader over Manchester attack comments
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he watched the interview with the Greens leader, Larissa Waters, and was left "stunned".

item.title: At least 16 injured after shooting in Sydney's Inner West | Evening News Bulletin 6 October 2025
item.description: At least 16 people injured in shooting at Sydney's inner west, Friend of an Australian activist in Israeli detention claims he's been physically abused by authorities, Ange Postecoglou under pressure at new Premier League side Nottingham Forest after fifth defeat.

item.title: "Excitement, then everything changed": survivors remember October 7 attack as calls grow for end to Gaza war
item.description: Thousands of Australians are joining vigils across the nation to mark the second anniversary of the deadly Hamas attack on Israel. Around 1200 people were killed and 250 taken hostage during the designated terror group's attack on October 7, 2023, which triggered a brutal military response from Israel.

item.title: Australian claims dislocated arm from soldiers in prison called Israel's 'worst'
item.description: Ketziot prison was once called the "largest and the worst" of Israel's prisons by Human Rights Watch. There are welfare concerns for Australians detained there.

item.title: Gold and copper prices surge and why you shouldn’t ignore your annual super statement
item.description: The ASX-200 has started the week in the red, as a tech sell-off offset strong gains by gold and copper miners. Plus, Japanese stocks have hit a record high just a day after the country’s ruling Liberal Democratic Party named Sanae Takaichi as its leader. For more, Rena Sarumpaet spoke with George Boubouras from K2 Asset Management. As annual superannuation statements start to arrive in the mail, Australians are being urged to not ignore them with research from Canstar showing about a fifth of respondents only check their super once every few years - or never. For more on how a financial health check could benefit your nest egg, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Canstar Data Insights Director Sally Tindall.

item.title: 'Fighting a war on two fronts': Behind the rise of a new threat in Gaza
item.description: Newly released data shows a major spike in intra-Palestinian violent incidents this year, as well as a significant rise in stolen aid packages.

item.title: The unseen impact of missing or damaged teeth — and the key to addressing it
item.description: Why is it so shameful to have missing teeth or gum disease? And what can we do about it?

item.title: Reflections on anniversary of October 7 attacks | Morning News Bulletin 7 October 2025
item.description: Papua New Guinea Prime Minister James Marape hails the new defence treaty with Australia; reflections on the second anniversary of the October 7 attacks; and in rugby league, the Newcastle Yowies win the men's and women's major titles at the Koori Knockout.

item.title: Australians from Gaza aid flotilla deported by Israel to Jordan following detention
item.description: Some of the Australian activists recently detained by Israel have alleged violence and mistreatment at the hands of soldiers.

item.title: Gaza peace talks to continue as October 7 anniversary marked by commemoration, protests
item.description: As Gaza marks two years under devastating Israeli bombardment, commemorations of the October 7 attacks and demonstrations in support of Palestinians are planned around the world.

item.title: University students panicked after fraudulent emails 'revoked', 'disqualified' degrees
item.description: Western Sydney University said the emails are "not legitimate" and have been reported to police.

item.title: NSW Premier backs police in protest fight | Midday News Bulletin 7 October 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, a court to decide whether a pro-Palestine protest will go ahead this weekend at the Opera House, Donald Trump heralds a breakthrough in Gaza peace talks. And in football, historic clubs return as the Australian Championship kicks off this weekend.

item.title: Advocates alarmed as major change for autistic kids looms
item.description: There are fears that many children with autism or learning difficulties will fall between the cracks of a new support system that aims to limit access to the National Disability Insurance Scheme. The Thriving Kids initiative will be rolled out from the middle of next year, with a focus on providing support to children with so-called mild to moderate autism within community and mainstream settings. But disability advocates have told a parliamentary inquiry it is these children that are most often overlooked or misunderstood.

item.title: Few women, minorities win seats in Syria's parliamentary election, initial results show
item.description: One of the election observers described the new parliament as overwhelmingly Sunni Muslim and male.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 7 October 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Federal government admits handballing truth-telling process as only 'half a person' employed
item.description: The Greens have questioned what progress is being made on truth-telling and treaty at a federal level.

item.title: Talks on Gaza peace plan progress - but can the sticking points be overcome?
item.description: Israeli and Hamas officials are meeting in Egypt this week in hopes of progressing a deal for a potential ceasefire in Gaza. It comes as the world marks two years of intense war in the enclave.

item.title: France plunges into chaos as anger mounts over political deadlock
item.description: French politics has been in disarray since President Emmanuel Macron called an early legislative election last year, producing a deeply fragmented National Assembly. Now, with Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu resigning after less than a month in the job, there are fears the French parliament has plunged into political deadlock.

item.title: 'You are not alone': PM and Ley recall horrors of Hamas attack, commemorating October 7
item.description: Both major party leaders have stood in solidarity with Australia's Jewish community as it remembers the Hamas-led attack on Israel.

item.title: 'The purpose of my voice is to teach history': Survivor tells how a party turned to trauma
item.description: Nova Festival attack survivor Natalie Sanandaji shares her ordeal escaping the massacre on 7 October 2023 in southern Israel.

item.title: GP snapshot reveals why the job has become more complicated
item.description: A snapshot of Australian general practice has revealed that GPs are having to see patients for longer appointments to treat more complex medical needs. The Health of the Nation industry survey of almost 2,500 GPs also shows a growing number of general practitioners are managing patient conditions typically handled by specialists.

item.title: ASIC approves ASX listing market competitor; is AI in a bubble? and gold approaches US$4,000
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Todd Hoare from LGT Wealth Management Australia Management about the day's sharemarket action, including ASIC's approval of Cboe Australia's listing market.

item.title: Government fast-tracks legislation to strengthen 000 call system
item.description: The government has fast-tracked legislation into parliament aimed at strengthening the 000 call system after failures by Optus to ensure access to emergency calls. As parliament resumed, the nation's leaders made time to commemorate the second anniversary of the October 7 attack on Israel by Hamas.

item.title: In pictures: Israel marks October 7 anniversary
item.description: Bereaved friends and family members gathered at the site of the Nova music festival, while others came together in Tel Aviv and held ceremonies across the country.

item.title: Fears over 'traumatising' home visits after minister flags disability system changes
item.description: Disability advocates are demanding clarity on upcoming NDIS changes, warning that the new system could be "traumatising".

item.title: Trump threatens to invoke centuries-old anti-insurrection law to militarise US cities
item.description: Donald Trump has said he would use the law to sidestep court rulings restricting orders to send National Guard troops into cities.

item.title: Trump threatens to invoke centuries-old anti-insurrection law to militarise US cities
item.description: Donald Trump has said he would use the law to sidestep court rulings restricting orders to send National Guard troops into cities.

item.title: Kneecap member vows to fight and win again as prosecutors appeal terrorism charge
item.description: UK prosecutors will appeal a court's decision to throw out a terrorism case against a member of the Irish rap trio.

item.title: Australians released from Israeli prison and deported to Jordan | Morning News Bulletin 8 October 2025
item.description: Seven Australians who were aboard the Gaza aid flotilla have been released from Israeli prison and deported to Jordan; the new Australian Federal Police Commissioner identifies social cohesion as a major focus under her leadership; and in Tennis, Australian Open organisers announce an event that will see professionals like Carlos Alcaraz face amateur players

item.title: INTERVIEW: The AFP's new commissioner, Krissy Barrett
item.description: The new Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police says her leadership will be characterised by a focus on social cohesion. Krissy Barrett, the first woman to lead the A-F-P, has amended the agency's mission statement to include "defend" and protect Australia from domestic and global security threats. In a wide ranging interview with SBS's Sara Tomevska, Commissioner Barrett says the agency will have a laser focus on disrupting crimes that impact Australia's sovereignty, democracy and social cohesion.

item.title: Three scientists win Nobel Prize in medicine
Missed the harvest moon? Here's when to see the next supermoons
item.description: The year's first supermoon happened on Tuesday night but don't worry, there are more on the way.

item.title: Revelations Optus e-mailed the wrong address about 000 outage | Midday News Bulletin 8 October 2025
item.description: Revelations Optus e-mailed the wrong government address about its triple zero outage... a renewed partnership between Australia and Singapore... and a bad start to the women's Champions League for three Matildas at Arsenal

item.title: Optus sent triple-zero outage notification to the wrong email address, department says
item.description: Companies had been told "a number of times" the email address was not to be used for notifications, a departmental staffer said.

item.title: Home Affairs knew for months 'ISIS brides' were returning; granted children citizenship
item.description: The federal government says the group, who arrived in Australia recently, are being monitored.

item.title: Home Affairs knew for months 'ISIS brides' were returning; granted children citizenship
item.description: The federal government says the group, who arrived in Australia recently, are being monitored.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 8 October 2025
item.description: A daily news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Australian Gaza aid flotilla activists deported by Israel amid claims of abuse
item.description: More ships are sailing towards Gaza as part of an international aid flotilla. It comes as Israel deports Australians who were part of the Global Sumud Flotilla.

item.title: Australian flotilla activist accuses government of 'shameful' Israel extraction effort
item.description: Australians were detained at what has been called an "outrageous" prison.

item.title: Opposition says minister didn't tell the truth about Optus outage | Evening News Bulletin 8 October 2025
item.description: More fallout fromn the Optus Triple zero scandal, with the opposition accusing the government of not telling the truth... new research shows women are genetically more likely to get depressed than men... and multiple reports that Australian captain Pat Cummins will not be fit for the start of the Ashes

item.title: Australia's cancer survival rates are improving — but there are also some 'concerning' trends
item.description: Australia's latest snapshot of cancer incidence and deaths has been released.

item.title: Gold breaks US$4,000 & is NZ becoming a better value tourist destination?
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Armina Rosenberg from Minotaur Capital about the day's market action, including gold's new milestone and how her firm is using AI to invest; plus Nick Tuffley from ASB Bank goes through why the RBNZ cut interest rates more than expected and what it means for Australian travellers going to New Zealand.

item.title: Communications minister accused of misleading parliament over Optus notification
item.description: The federal opposition has accused Communications Minister Anika Wells of misleading parliament over when her office was notified of the Optus Triple-Zero outage that has been linked to four deaths. It comes as emails that Optus sent to notify the government and the regulator of the outages, which ultimately affected more than 600 people last month, are scrutinised in Senate estimates. Meanwhile, legislation creating a triple-zero custodian has passed the lower house.

item.title: There's a difference between hot and cold sweat — and one tends to smell more distinctive
item.description: Cold sweat is known as psychological sweat, while hot sweat is often the body's response to physical exertion.

item.title: 'Deeply harmful': Autism advocates fear major change for some Australian children
item.description: The government is pushing ahead with a new program — and there are concerns it could leave some children falling between the cracks.

item.title: Prison guards thought TJ was 'playing possum'. Hours later, he was dead
item.description: TJ's death in custody prompted an apology by Corrective Services NSW. But did he ever stand a chance of leaving?

item.title: Court to decide on pro-Palestinian protest at Sydney Opera House | Morning News Bulletin 9 October 2025
item.description: A court is set to decide if pro-Palestinian protest at Sydney Opera House will go ahead; A man's been charged with starting the deadly Pacific Palisades fires in January; And in netball, The Diamonds clinch victory in three-game series against South Africa.

item.title: Former FBI chief James Comey pleads not guilty in case pushed by Trump
item.description: Donald Trump has threatened to imprison his political rivals since the start of his 2016 presidential campaign.

item.title: Australian professor Richard Robson among Nobel Prize chemistry winners
item.description: The discovery for the Nobel chemistry prize has been likened to a Harry Potter enchanted handbag.

item.title: 'Light at the end of the tunnel’: Darfur victims welcome ICC verdict
item.description: The International Criminal Court has convicted Sudanese militia commander Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-Al-Rahman of war crimes and crimes against humanity for leading attacks in Darfur over 20 years ago. The conviction marks the ICC's first conviction for atrocities in the Darfur conflict which killed an estimated 300,000 people and forcibly displaced around 2.7 million.

item.title: Senior US officials arrive in Egypt for Gaza peace talks as Israeli assault dials down
item.description: Donald Trump said a deal was "very close" and that he may travel to the Middle East this weekend.

item.title: Could Donald Trump win the 2025 Nobel Peace Prize?
item.description: Leaders seeking to curry favour with Trump have been quick to talk up the US president's chances, but experts aren't so sure.

item.title: Pro-Palestinian marchers plan new route after court blocks Opera House rally
item.description: Organisers said their right to protest was "paramount" after their initial plan was blocked following a court challenge.

item.title: Trump says 'first phase' of Gaza peace deal reached; hostages to be released within days
item.description: Arab countries backing the plan say it must lead to eventual independence for a Palestinian state.

item.title: What we've learnt about the 'ISIS brides', as federal police anticipate more returns
item.description: The Australian Federal Police said the group, which has returned from Syria, was being monitored as part of an ongoing operation.

item.title: Trump says Gaza peace plan first phase agreed to by Israel and Hamas | Midday News Bulletin 9 October 2025
item.description: Donald Trump says Israel and Hamas have agreed to the first phase of a Gaza peace plan; an Australian scientist wins the Nobel Prize in Chemistry; and Cristiano Ronaldo becomes the first footballer to reach billionaire status.

item.title: INTERVIEW: What does the Middle East peace deal mean?
item.description: US President Donald Trump says Israel and Hamas have agreed on the first phase of a peace framework that will allow for the release of all hostages. In a post on social media, he said the release of hostages is imminent, adding that "All Parties will be treated fairly!". The exchange of the remaining hostages held by Hamas for Palestinian prisoners could happen within 72 hours of the deal's implementation. Dr Eyal Mayroz is a lecturer in Peace and Conflict Studies at the University of Sydney, and he gave SBS's Cameron Carr his reaction to the agreement

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 9 October 2025
item.description: A daily news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: The Gaza peace deal's first phase has been agreed to. But there are still many questions
item.description: Despite the hopes raised for ending the war, crucial details are yet to be spelled out.

item.title: 'A ray of light': Albanese, Ley applaud delivery of Trump's Gaza peace plan
item.description: Both major party leaders say the breakthrough in Gaza gives "hope" to the world that Donald Trump's peace plan is "the start of the end of this war".

item.title: New workplace laws aim to remove extra pain burden on parents arising from stillbirth
item.description: Laws have been introduced into federal parliament to stop employers from scrapping leave entitlements when families face the tragedy of a stillbirth or death of their baby.

item.title: Sign off on first phase of Gaza peace deal welcomed | Evening News Bulletin 9 October 2025
item.description: Australia welcomes Israel and the Hamas signing the first phase of peace deal; India's Defence Minister visits Australia, as both countries deepen defence ties; and in sport, Matildas coach Joe Montem calls for more investment in A-League Women teams.

item.title: The common mortgage feature that could be leaving you 'worse off'
item.description: Mortgage offset accounts have helped many Australians wipe interest off their home loan. But they don't always offer a benefit.

item.title: Gaza peace deal market impacts & Gemini crypto exchange enters Australia
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Robert Talevski to see how the Gaza peace deal has impacted markets; and Ricardo takes a look at Australia's crypto regulatory space with Gemini's Saad Ahmed.

item.title: Israel and Hamas have agreed on the first phase of a Gaza peace deal. Now what?
item.description: Israel and Hamas have agreed to the first phase of United States President Donald Trump's plan for Gaza. The ceasefire and hostage deal could be a first step toward ending a bloody two-year-old war that has roiled across the Middle East.

item.title: A Gaza peace deal signed; au revoir to yet another French PM; & Australia's new security alliance
item.description: Hamas and Israel sign up for Phase One of Trump's new 20-point plan for peace in Gaza. France's revolving door on its prime ministerial office takes another spin. Plus Australia and PNG sign on to an expanded alliance for regional cooperation. And how desperate for $5,000 are you? Take a job at a haunted hotel desperate?

item.title: In pictures: Palestinians and Israelis celebrate after news of ceasefire deal
item.description: Israel and Hamas are expected to sign the agreement at the Egyptian beach resort of Sharm el-Sheikh on Thursday.

item.title: Fear drove Fouad to Australia. Even after a major milestone, his hopes are dim
item.description: Fouad Berzghal's home country had its first election since the fall of its dictator. But there are questions over how much will change.

item.title: 'It felt like home': Why generations of migrant Australians love the NPL
item.description: Once the lifeblood of migrant communities, suburban football clubs are back on the national stage for the Australian Championship.

item.title: Donald Trump says Israeli hostages should be home early next week | Morning News Bulletin 10 October 2025
item.description: Donald Trump says Israeli hostages should be home early next week as the world welcomes a Gaza ceasefire deal; The government under pressure over FOI laws; And in sport, Novak Djokovic through to semi-finals of Shanghai Masters.

item.title: What’s the Senate actually estimating? Ft. David Pocock
item.description: The first senate estimates of the 48th Parliament have arrived – where the Albanese Labor Government and representatives from the Australian Public Service and government agencies are quizzed for up to 14 hours a day about pretty much anything. It’s tedious, it’s long, but it’s all about accountability, and Independent Senator for the ACT David Pocock takes us behind the scenes. Plus Bob Katter has a suggestion for the footy off-season, and Andrew Hastie has left the Coalition front bench.

item.title: 'Safe beds save lives': Calls for urgent action to address rising number of homeless women
item.description: Australians are being urged to recognise the link between domestic violence and homelessness, as more women face sleeping rough.

item.title: Phase one of Gaza peace deal set to begin after approval by Israeli cabinet
item.description: Despite celebrations in Israel and Gaza and a flood of messages from world leaders hailing the deal, numerous issues remain unsettled.

item.title: Phase one of Gaza peace deal set to begin after approval by Israeli cabinet
item.description: Despite celebrations in Israel and Gaza and a flood of messages from world leaders hailing the deal, numerous issues remain unsettled.

item.title: Australia welcomes Gaza peace plan, urges two-state solution | Midday News Bulletin 10 October 2025
item.description: Israel's cabinet approves phase one of a Gaza peace plan; Indigenous artists celebrated at the Australian Women in Music Awards; And in sport, Australia remain top of the Women's Cricket World Cup League standings

item.title: Australia welcomes Gaza peace plan, urges two-state solution | Midday News Bulletin 10 October 2025
item.description: Israel's cabinet approves phase one of a Gaza peace plan; Indigenous artists celebrated at the Australian Women in Music Awards; And in sport, Australia remain top of the Women's Cricket World Cup League standings

item.title: Are Syria’s first post-Assad elections strengthening or weakening democracy?
item.description: Syria's first parliamentary elections since the fall of Bashar al-Assad have sparked criticism for how they were run. The election was seen as a key step in the shift away from the al-Assad regime, but one that has sparked concerns about inclusivity and fairness under the country's new leaders. Syrians here in Australia say their relatives at home do not feel represented by the new Government.

item.title: Pocock won't rejoin parliamentary sports club despite ban reversal
item.description: The former Wallabies captain says he won’t take part in Parliament’s friendly sporting matches unless the club rethinks its corporate ties.

item.title: Peace in the Middle East greeted with joy across the divide
item.description: After two years of devastating conflict, there are scenes of cautious celebration across the Middle East. A historic ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas, brokered by US President Donald Trump, has been reached, in effect, marking what some are calling a new chapter of peace.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 10 October 2025
item.description: A daily news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Australian flotilla activist faces indefinite Israeli detention 'threat', as others return home
item.description: The returned activists have concerns for Madeline Habib, who is said to be in "good health" while detained in Israel.

item.title: Tsunami threat passes after powerful earthquake strikes Philippines
item.description: A tsunami alert for the Philippines, Palau and Indonesia has been lifted following a magnitude 7.4 earthquake south of the Philippines.

item.title: Unveiled: New 60-day plan for Gaza after ceasefire begins
item.description: The United Nations says it's prepared for a humanitarian aid "surge" once the Gaza ceasefire begins.

item.title: How a 'deeply-embedded' part of Australian culture could change forever
item.description: Young Australians are leading this emerging generational shift, according to a new study.

item.title: US troops deployed to help monitor Gaza ceasefire deal | Evening News Bulletin 10 October 2025
item.description: US troops deployed to Israel to help monitor the Gaza ceasefire deal; an earthquake triggers a tsunami warning for the Philippines and neighbouring regions of Indonesia; and in football, Sam Kerr returns to the Matildas squad.

item.title: The looming Europe travel change that will affect Australians
item.description: New personal data collection rules are about to come into effect in Europe's Schengen area. Here's what you need to know.

item.title: Silver at highest since 1980 & how markets are reacting to Gaza peace deal
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Zoran Kresovic from Blueberry Markets about the day's market action, including how investors are feeling following the potential Gaza peace deal, the future for gold and the outlook for silver, which hit a near 45 year high.

item.title: Venezuelan opposition figure María Corina Machado awarded Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: A total of 338 nominations were submitted for the award, including 244 individuals and 94 organisations.

item.title: Venezuelan opposition figure María Corina Machado awarded Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: A total of 338 nominations were submitted for the award, including 244 individuals and 94 organisations.

item.title: Gaza ceasefire in effect and troops withdrawing, Israeli military announces
item.description: A massive column of displaced Gazans filed north through the dust towards Gaza City after the ceasefire came into effect at midday Friday.
